Award.AwardTitle: The community context of genotype-by-genotype interactions: implications for biological invasions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Just as in human populations, individuals of a single species differ in traits that influence their survival in different environments. The genetic variation that underlies these trait differences may be especially important for exotic species that invade new areas, as populations without individuals that can tolerate the novel environment may not be able to establish and successfully reproduce. Similarly, individuals of native plants may differ in their ability to resist invasion or coexist with invaders because of genetic differences. The proposed research examines how the genetics of two plant species in California grasslands, one native and one exotic, affect the invasion success of the exotic species. Interactions between different genetic individuals of the two species will be examined in the presence and absence of insects that eat the plants to determine how environmental differences may also affect invasions by exotic plants. This project thus incorporates the relatively new field of community genetics (simultaneously examining genetic variation in multiple, co-occurring species) with invasion biology, and will provide important insights for related studies.

A postdoctoral researcher, graduate student, and undergraduate students will be trained and mentored in this research. Curriculum focused on invasive species biology will be developed for a K-12 program based at the Kellogg Biological Station in Michigan. A more complete understanding of the invasion process may help prevent future invasions that may be both ecologically and economically costly and also may aid in ensuring the success of intentional introductions (e.g., for biological control or cultivation).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological invasions are a mystery. Human have unintentionally introduced species from around the world into new areas, yet most introduced species fail to establish because successfully colonizing and establishing in a new environment is exceptionally challenging. Yet invasive species are pervasive and responsible for many ecological and economic problems. We find that there is a tremendous amount of variation between individuals (“genetic variation”) of the invasive plant Medicago polymorpha in traits that influence survival in different environments. As a result, certain Medicago individuals, or “genotypes”, are better at invading different sites than others, and successful invasions likely depend on the match between the invading genotype and local environmental conditions. For example, some genotypes are more susceptible to insect damage making them less likely to invade areas with high insect densities. Similarly, earlier flowering is advantageous in some environments, while delayed flowering is advantageous in other environments.

Traits are not static, and evolution of the invasive species can alter invasion success and interactions between the invader and native species. For example, we find that invasive species can evolve during the invasion process in ways that make them larger and more successful in high resource, low competition environments. Fortunately, these evolutionary increases in size do not lead to greater negative impacts on co-occurring native species. In another example, Medicago has evolved to benefit more from local rhizobium variants (belowground bacteria that provide plants with nitrogen), which increases Medicago’s reproductive success. A more complete understanding of the invasion process, including the roles that genetic variation and evolution play in biological invasions, may help prevent future invasions that may be both ecologically and economically costly and also may aid in ensuring the success of intentional introductions (e.g., for biological control or cultivation).

We have collaborated with teachers from local public school districts to make our science accessible and exciting to middle and high school students. Our teacher collaborators have worked with us to develop and test “Data Nuggets,” short worksheets that help introduce students to the scientific method and graphing and interpreting data (www.datanuggets.org). Another teacher collaborator developed an electronic “e-lab” comprised of photographs of native and invasive species so that students can test one of the major explanations for the success of invasive species—that invasive species are so successful because they have escaped their enemies and experience less damage from insects, mammals and diseases than native species. In addition, we have trained numerous high school, undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral researchers. All of these trainees have pursued further education or careers in the biological sciences or science education.
